DataElement.preferredName: Bone Scan Medical Imaging Assessment Neoplasm Occurrence Frequency
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to represent the identification of lesions during a bone scan assessment.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to the medical imaging assessment (the determination of the value, significance, or extent of) to create images of bones on a computer screen or on film.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A technique to create images of bones on a computer screen or on film. A small amount of radioactive material is injected into a blood vessel and travels through the bloodstream; it collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.:In medicine, any technology which helps in visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for the screening, diagnosis, surgical procedure or therapy.

Concepts.definition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.
In medicine, any technology which helps in visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for the screening, diagnosis, surgical procedure or therapy.

Property.preferredDefinition: The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a description of the quantity of tumors identified in the bladder at the time of study entry._An abnormal tissue growth resulted from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant ones exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias. -- 2004 (NCI)_An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident._The number of occurrences of something within a given time period. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not accompanied by another or others.

Concepts.definition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.

Concepts.definition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:Occurrence; an instance of something happening.:The number of occurrences of something within a given time period. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.
The number of occurrences of something within a given time period.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support MGH Imaging trial
